Ian Badcoe wrote:

>At 23:49 26/08/2004, you wrote:
>  
>
>>Colin Green wrote:
>>    
>>
>>I just had another idea. If I remember correctly, in nature genes are
>>usually marked out with certain short sequences of DNA. Perhaps we could
>>introduce the concept of a marker gene into the NEAT genome. We could
>>then implement a multipoint crossover technique that is marker aware and
>>hopefully genes would become re-ordered into functionaly dependent
>>groups far more efficiently than using plain old random multipoint
>>crossover. [...]
>>
>
>
>I guess you are talking about the common, short repetitive sequences found 
>in the Junk DNA?
>
>They are not used as labels.  It's purely position on the chromosome and 
>homology between the two chromosomes which determines their alignment 
>before crossover (they are physically lined-up next to each other). 
>
I may be getting confused. I think I read an article about finding genes 
within all the data generated by the human genome project, I think there 
are certain sequences that indicate that a gene end is nearby. In fact 
they could well include the repeated sequences you mentioned - yes I 
read something on those also. But because a tell tale sequence exists 
does not mean that the genetic machinery is actually using it. Sure.

> There 
>is (used to be) some talk that repetitive sequences increase the 
>probability of sequence duplication (which happens by misaligning the 
>chromosomes before crossover, and leads to one output with two copies of a 
>section, and one with none).
>  
>
There was something in a recent Sci.Am. I think it was related to 
sections of DNA that didn't twist back into the double helix properly, 
forming loops that stick out from the main DNA helix. During duplication 
they get jammed in the machinery, say like a piece of paper getting 
stuck in the photocopier thus causing the copy to have an even longer 
repreated sequence.

>Don't let that stop you, however, we don't need to take every idea from nature.
>  
>
I'm developing the idea. I'll keep the group posted.


>--
>
>What you are describing is what I call an Arbitrary Label System 
>(ALS).  It's part of a body of proposed research that I am slowly writing 
>up as a position document.  I will announce the document here when I get it 
>done.  (I'm not claiming to have invented the idea, I don't know where I 
>got it from.)
>
>  
>
Have you read the Modular NEAT paper? Sounds similar except your labels 
could be used to connect up disperate networks right, whereas Mod. NEAT 
modules always connect between the input and output layers, they don;t 
connect to each other.

Colin.
